qas.question: What kind of inscriptions decorate Punjab's burial places?
What color tile was used in Ahangar's tomb?
Where does the structure of a mosque come from?
What colour is the tomb of Shah Yusuf Gardezi?
When did Emperor Shah Jahan live?
Where was Emperor Shah Jahan buried?

context: The structure of a mosque is simple and it expresses openness. <a0_0>Calligraphic inscriptions from <b5_0>the Quran<b5_0/><a0_0/> decorate mosques and mausoleums in Punjab. The inscriptions on bricks and tiles of the mausoleum of Shah Rukn-e-Alam (<a1_0>1320 AD<a1_0/>) at Multan are outstanding specimens of architectural calligraphy. The earliest existing building in South Asia with enamelled tile-work is the tomb of Shah Yusuf Gardezi (<a2_0><b7_0>1150 AD<b7_0/><a2_0/>) at <b8_0>Multan<b8_0/>. A specimen of the <a3_0>sixteenth century<a3_0/> tile-work at Lahore is the tomb of Sheikh Musa Ahangar, with its brilliant <a4_0><b6_0>blue<b6_0/><a4_0/> dome. The tile-work of <b9_0>Emperor Shah Jahan<b9_0/> is of a richer and more elaborate nature. The pictured wall of Lahore Fort is the last line in the tile-work in the entire world.
